results.title: Bitter Herbs and Honey
results.creator_credit: Monique Schwarz, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Amber Films
results.brief_description: Australian documentary focuses on the lives of European Jews who settled in the Melbourne suburb of Carlton in the 1940s, fleeing World War II atrocities and post-War conditions. Interestingly the Jews from Eastern Europe clashed with Anglo-Jews, settled in the nineteenth century, who identified as British rather than Jewish and disapproved of the too obvious presence of Sephardic Jews, with whom they feared association. Despite these and other difficulties, social groups thrived in the suburb, where people shared life, food, religion and a common experience. Local residents from the period, many recalling their childhood, discuss a marvellously rich and joyous, if impoverished, family life; others talk about the racism suffered at school and in the street; several recount the pain of being a Holocaust survivor and the trials of assimilation. Includes archival footage from the era interspersed with recreations and a slew of interviews that include: Pinchus Ringelblum, Hilary Rubinstein, Bernard Rechter, Solomon Pose, Victor Smorgon, Arnord Zable, Jean Holkner, June Factor, Freydi Mrocki, Sam Lipski, Amirah Inglis, Rachel Levita and Miriam Kuna. Features some marvellous Yiddish songs and several interviewees discuss their parents yearning to sustain the use of Yiddish language. With occasional English subtitles.

results.title: Rights from the heart. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Therese Descary and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: These seven short animated films from the National Film Board of Canada are united by their inspiration from the 1990 United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. Each film addresses a specific right that was agreed upon by the convention. They are designed to encourage children to think about the world in which they live. The films contain no dialogue. Part 2 is intended for children aged 9-12. The films are Jonas and Lisa” (dirs: Zabelle Cote, Daniel Schorr); “The Tournament (dir: Francine Desbiens); “Overdose” (dir: Claude Cloutier); “An artist” (Dir: Michele Cournoyer); “Baroque’n roll” (dir: Pierre M. Trudeau); “Ex-child” (dir: Jacques Drouin); “Why?” (dir: Bretislav Pojar). A resource guide for educators is included.

results.title: Rights from the heart. Part 3
results.brief_description: These seven short animated films from the National Film Board of Canada are united by their inspiration from the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. Included on the tape are: DUEL; A child who has been brainwashed with censored information to make him a model citizen rebels against all forms of censorship of the mind when he becomes an adult. NARCO BLUES; An ordinary teenager is unwillingly pulled into the harsh world of drugs. However an incident has a salutory effect on him. THE CORA PLAYER; Two young Africans from different social backgrounds defy tradition by falling in love. LOCKED; A boy is seized by an enormous hand that pushes him towards a hazardous lock factory- symobolizing innocence murdered by forced child labour. TRADE; A young Indian girl is sold by her parents to a pimp who takes her to work in a brothel. MASKS; Throughout childhood and adulthood a young man refuses to wear the “masks” imposed on him by social convention. DEATHTRAP; A young man closes all the doors to his heart, but seeing that suicide is a trap, decides to live. In English and French language.

results.title: Three "I"s: a trio of personal films about Sweden by two Canadians and one Swede
results.creator_credit: Martin Duckworth, Mort Ransen, Eric M Nilsson, John Kemeny, Wolf Koenig, Joseph Koenig, Swedish Institute for Cultural Relations and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film trilogy presenting impressions of Sweden by two Canadians and one Swede: Mort Ransen and Martin Duckworth of the National Film Board, and Swedish director Eric M. Nilsson. The film is composed of three films: “A Place for everything” - Eric Nilsson takes up the contrasts in the well-ordered Swedish society - order versus spontaneity; individual desires set against collective needs; subordinares vis-a-vis superiors. The young Swedes interviewed make a plea for independence, imagination and the discussion of existing conditions. “Falling from ladders” - Simply by putting about 20 Swedish men, women and young people in front of his camera and having them read aloud from the Statistical Year Book, filmmaker Mort Ransen has recorded a wide range of impressions of Sweden’s economic and social existence. Quotations vary from the whole gamut of exports and imports, marriages formed or dissolved, to the number of people who fall from ladders annually. (Award: Philadelphia) “Passing through Sweden” - A film critic of one of Sweden’s daily newspapers says of this film by Martin Duckworth, “Never before have I seen a film that so intensely interpreted the experience of Swedish surroundings…an ‘atmospheric film’ in which all the expression is in the pictures.”
results.title_for_label: Three “I”s: a trio of personal films about Sweden by two Canadians and one Swede

results.title: Fidel Castro: maximum leader
results.creator_credit: Stephen Leigh, Carlton International, Mentorn International and Reel
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Famous lives”.
‘Fidel Castro: maximum leader’ chronicles the rise of Cuba’s most infamous dignitary. Born in an era when Cuba was the playground of Americans fleeing prohibition, Castro became interested in student activism and witnessed the changing of leaders between Presidents Gomez and Battista. He led a gang of guerrilla rebels into the mountains, and after several unsuccessful insurrections into the capital, was finally successful in overthrowing Battista - thanks to intervention by Eisenhower. Throughout his career Castro would form Communist alliances and create a highly sensitive relationship between Cuba and America. Includes footage from the Cuban Missile Crisis and the Bay of Pigs invasion. Narrated by Lucy Longhurst.

results.title: The Butler
results.creator_credit: Anna Kannava, John Cruthers and Huzzah Productions
results.brief_description: An intimate portrait of a Greek family and their experience of migration and integration into Australian life. Nino, the youngest, is the vehicle used to explore the alienation and shock that are part of migration, the complexity of family relationships and the integration of the intellectually disabled into the community. “The Butler” is the sequel to “Ten years after, ten years older” also held in the collection.

results.title: Woodstock: 3 days of peace & music (S) (Director's cut) [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Michael Wadleigh, Bob Maurice and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Winner of the Best Documentary Feature at the 1970 Academy Awards, director Michael Wadleigh’s film captures the spirit of Woodstock- three days of peace and music. Included on the tape are performances from the following artists: Crosby, Stills and Nash, Canned Heat, Richie Havens, Joan Baez, The Who, Sha-Na-Na, Joe Cocker and the Grease Band, Country Joe and the Fish, Arlo Guthrie, Ten Years After, Jefferson Airplane, John Sebastian, Country Joe McDonald, Santana, Sly and the Family Stone, Janis Joplin and Jimi Hendrix.

results.title: The Jimi Hendrix Experience: electric ladyland
results.creator_credit: Roger Pomphrey, Bous De Jong, Nick de Grunewald, BBC, Experience Hendrix, Daniel Television and Isis Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Classic albums: the greatest records in rock history”.
Jimi Hendrix’s album “Electric Ladyland” is one of the classic rock albums of the 20th century. With songs like “Voodoo Chile”, “Crosstown Traffic”, “Gypsy Eyes”, and “All Along the Watchtower”, it has influenced countless rock guitarists. This documentary, part of the “Classic Album” series, examines both the recording process of the album as well as focusing on the life and legend of Jimi Hendrix. Examining each song on the album, the documentary intersperses interviews with Hendrix’s friends and musicians who played on the album, with footage of Hendrix both playing and being interviewed, photos (including Linda McCartney’s pictures for the album cover), and Hendrix’s notes and journals as well as lots of amazing music. People interviewed include Chas Chandler, Mitch Mitchell, Noel Redding, Buddy Miles, Dave Mason, Mike Finnigan, Steve Winwood and album engineer Eddie Krammer.

results.title: Stiletto [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Louise Leroux, Eric Michel and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: ‘Stiletto’ is an intriguing investigation of society’s fascination with fetishistic footwear. The impact of the stiletto heel on both fashion and culture is scrutinised from a number of perspectives by people including an historian, a podiatrist, a fashion therapist, a fashion designer, and the manufacturers of fetishistic shoes. Looks at stilettos in relation to roleplay, festishism, gender roles, foot- binding, and images of sexuality, using archival footage and photo- graphic stills as supporting evidence.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Louise Leroux, Eric Michel and National Film Board of Canada
results.description: ‘Stiletto’ is an intriguing investigation of society’s fascination with fetishistic footwear. The impact of the stiletto heel on both fashion and culture is scrutinised from a number of perspectives by people including an historian, a podiatrist, a fashion therapist, a fashion designer, and the manufacturers of fetishistic shoes. Looks at stilettos in relation to roleplay, festishism, gender roles, foot- binding, and images of sexuality, using archival footage and photo- graphic stills as supporting evidence.
